Athos da Silveira Ramos 149, CT Bl E, 21941-909 Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil. Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro Escola de Química Av. Athos da Silveira Ramos 149 CT Bl E 21941-909 Rio de Janeiro RJ Brazil Graphical abstract The effect of copper as dopant on ceria (CeO2) was investigated in the direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol. Ceria with different copper loadings (0.02 and 0.5 wt%) was synthesized using the dry impregnation method and characterized by H2-TPR, XRD, EPR, UV–VIS/DRS, acid-base properties and N2 physisorption. CeO2 with 0.02 wt% of Cu showed the highest catalytic activity and selectivity to DMC, mostly due to its basic sites, associated with the presence of oxygen vacancies. Higher Cu concentration (0.5 wt%) promotes dehydrogenation, favoring the formation of methyl formate as the main product. Pure CeO2 also produced dimethoxymethane as by-product. To circumvent the thermodynamic limitations of the reaction, methyl trichloroacetate was tested as dehydrating agent, showing superior performance than 2-cyanopyridine, due to its higher reactivity toward hydrolysis. Keywords CeO2 CO2 Dimethyl carbonate Copper Methyl trichloroacetate Oxygen vacancy 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide is the main greenhouse gas to contribute to global warming. It is emitted upon the burning of fuels, such as petroleum, coal and natural gas [1,2]. It is also an abundant, non-flammable, cheap and non-toxic resource, which can be utilized in the synthesis of a variety of chemicals [3,4]. However, the transformation of CO2 to other valuable products usually requires high energy input, because the CO2 molecule is thermodynamically stable and presents low reactivity. Proper catalysts and optimum reaction conditions are necessary for successful conversion to different commercial products. Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) is a promising chemical due to its non-toxic and biodegradable character. It is used in electrolytic solutions of lithium ion batteries and as an additive in gasoline-based fuels [4]. It is also employed as methylating agent and starting material for the production of polycarbonates [5–7]. The global consumption of DMC in 2016 was around 90kt [8] with a market value of over US$ 467 million [9]. Many routes have been developed for the synthesis of DMC. Among them are the reaction of methanol with phosgene, the oxycarbonylation with carbon monoxide, transesterification of propylene carbonate or ethylene carbonate and methanolysis of urea [4]. The synthesis of DMC using phosgene has been gradually discontinued due to the high toxicity of this reactant. It provided, typically, 82 to 85% yield of product, but requires considerable amounts of NaOH to neutralize the HCl formed as by-product [10]. DMC synthesis from CO2 and methanol is still poorly applied because of thermodynamic limitations (Scheme 1 ) [11]. Homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been employed to convert methanol and CO2 into DMC and water. The homogeneous catalysts are difficult to be separated [12] from the medium and thus, present limited industrial interest. On the other hand, heterogeneous catalysts are easily separated from the reaction medium and mostly used in industrial processes. Various heterogeneous catalysts have been studied in the synthesis of DMC. Among them are, for instance, ZrO2 [13], TiO2 [14], CeO2 and its mixed oxides (Ce1−yZryO2) [15,16]. The oxygen mobility, oxygen vacancies [17] and the ability to perform redox reactions without changing the crystalline structure attract the attention to the use of CeO2 in catalysis [18–20]. Many authors have reported that, for the synthesis of DMC, the acid and base properties of CeO2, as well as the reducibility of the surface oxygen atoms, are important factors in determining the catalytic activity [6,21–24]. The proposed mechanistic pathway to DMC involves the adsorption of methanol on basic sites to form methoxy species (CH3O−) [25], which then reacts with CO2 to afford methoxy carbonate (−OC(O)OCH3) [21,26,27]. Finally, methoxy carbonate species reacts with another methanol molecule to yield DMC [26]. Lee et al. [28] reported that Ce0.6Zr0.4O2 catalyst mixed with Ga2O3 showed good catalytic performance in the direct synthesis of DMC from methanol and carbon dioxide. The dependence of the DMC yield with the acid-base properties was also investigated by Kumar et al. [7], using mixed oxides of cerium and calcium, with different Ce/Ca molar ratios, as catalysts. The oxide with Ce/Ca molar ratio of 1 showed the best performance due to its combined acid-base properties. It has been reported that ceria doped with Al (3 wt%) can be used in the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol. The deactivation of the ceria catalyst is caused by the surface modification, upon the reduction of Ce (IV) to Ce (III) which is inert for this reaction [12]. Indeed, it has been reported [29] that the catalytic activity of CeXZr1−XO2 is dependent on the concentration of Ce4+ on the surface and the increase in the acidity and basicity. Recently, Tamboli et al. [30] described a series of ceria/zirconia (CexZr1−xO2) solid solutions in the direct synthesis of DMC. The authors mentioned that the enhanced catalytic activity was due to the high BET area, surface oxygen vacancy and distinct morphology. Wada et al. [31] reported a catalytic study of reduced CeO2 doped with Cu in the production of DMC. The reduction of the Ce atoms was effective to improve the yield, creating oxygen vacancies that may adsorb CO2. Cu (0.1 wt%) incorporation into the CeO2 lattice significantly affects the catalytic activity. Authors mentioned that adsorption of CO2 is probably the key step in the synthesis of DMC and that oxygen vacancies should increase upon the reduction of the catalyst. However, the biggest challenge associated with the direct synthesis of DMC from CO2 is the strong thermodynamic limitations of the reaction, which shows an unfavorable equilibrium to the products (Scheme 1). The addition of dehydrating agents to remove the water from the reaction medium, shifts the equilibrium, enabling to achieve high yields of DMC [32,33]. Several reagents, such as nitriles [34] and acetals/ketals [35] have been used as dehydrating agents in the synthesis of DMC. Among them, 2-cyanopyridyne (2-CP) [36] can be highlighted due to the good results when CeO2 is used as catalyst. Nevertheless, the hydrolysis of 2-CP produces many by-products (amides, carbamates and esters) that are somewhat difficult to be recycled to the original nitrile or do not have a proper destination. Therefore, this point makes the process less sustainable, in spite of the use of CO2 as reagent and the higher yields of DMC observed. In a previous work [37], we demonstrated that methyl trichloroacetate (MTCL) can be used as dehydrating agent in the synthesis of DMC. The electron withdrawing capability of the CCl3 group increases the reactivity of the carbonyl group of MTCL toward hydrolysis, improving the DMC yield. Furthermore, the hydrolysis of the esters affords carboxylic acids, which can be potentially separated from the medium and recycled to the methyl esters through traditional esterification procedures. Thus, the use of trihaloacetate esters as dehydrating agents could lead to more sustainable processes for the synthesis of organic carbonates. In this contribution we wish to show the role of Cu in Cu-CeO2 based catalysts employed in the synthesis of DMC, as well as the concomitant use of dehydrating agent to shift the equilibrium and increase the yield of the product. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation CeO2 was synthesized by precipitation of [(NH4)2Ce(NO3)6] with a 30% solution of NH4OH, which was quickly added to a solution containing the Ce salt (0.4 mol L−1), under vigorous stirring and at room temperature. The solid was filtered and washed with deionized water before calcination at 500 °C for 1 h (10 °C min−1). The catalysts containing different Cu loading (0.02, 0.04, 0.1 and 0.5 wt%) were prepared upon the dry impregnation of the CeO2 previously prepared. The Cu(NO3)2·2.5H2O was employed as precursor. It was dissolved in water and this solution was added dropwise to the support. The volume of the aqueous solution added to ceria was calculated considering the previously measured pore volume of this oxide. The solids were dried overnight at 100 °C and calcined at 500 °C for 4 h (10 °C min−1). 2.2 Catalytic tests The reactions were carried out in a 100 mL Parr® batch reactor with 50 bar of CO2 under magnetic stirring. The temperature of the reaction, the catalyst loading and the amount of methanol were 140 or 170 °C, 100 mg and 15 mL, respectively. After 3 h, the reactor was cooled down and the catalyst was separated by centrifugation. The products were analyzed by gas chromatograph (Agilent 6850) equipped with a mass spectrometer (MS) detector, using a capillary column of 5%-phenyl-methyl siloxane. Injector and detector temperatures were 220 and 250 °C, respectively. Helium was used as a carrier gas with a flow rate of 0.7 mL min−1. The collection of the products in the gas phase was carried out using a SamplePro® Flex Film air sample bag, with single combined polypropylene hose/valve and septum for economy and light weight. The products were analyzed by GC–MS at similar conditions used to quantify the products in the liquid phase. The definition of specific product selectivity (Sp) is the ratio of the number of carbon moles consumed to synthesize this compound to the sum of carbon moles consumed to synthesize the compounds (Eq. (1)). The methanol conversion (XCH3OH) was defined as the ratio of moles of carbon consumed to synthesize the compounds to the moles of methanol introduced in the feed (Eq. (2)). (1) S P % = carbon m o l c o n s u m e d t o s y n t h e t i z e d p r o d u c t p carbon m o l c o n s u m e d · 100 (2) X C H 3 O H % = carbon m o l c o n s u m e d number o f i n i t i a l c a r b o n m o l · 100 (3) carbon m o l c o n s u m e d = ∑ c a r b o n m o l c o n s u m e d t o s y n t h e t i z e d p n 2.3 Catalyst characterization The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of the catalysts was obtained by N2 adsorption carried out at −196 °C, employing a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The samples (oxidized) were dried at 100 °C for 24 h, and then submitted to in situ vacuum treatment (lower than 10−5 atm) at 350 °C for 2 h. The area was calculated taken the data of relative pressure between 0.1 and 0.3. The H2-TPR was carried out under a flow (50 mL min−1) of 10% H2 diluted in N2, increasing the temperature to 1000 °C by 10 °C min−1. The amount of H2 consumed during the reduction was measured by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Reduction profiles were normalized using the mass of the samples and the H2 signal intensity. The catalysts were pre-treated to eliminate surface carbonated species generated upon exposure to air during handling and storage [38]. Before the experiments the catalysts were pretreated at 130 °C for 30 min under N2 flow (30 mL min−1) and reduced under 10% H2/N2 flow (50 mL min−1) at 500 °C (10 °C min−1) for 1 h. After that, the catalysts were oxidized under synthetic air flow (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 30 min. The catalyst structural properties were investigated by means of X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer equipped with CuKα (1.5406 Å) and a nickel filter, Bragg-Brentano geometry, with X-ray tube voltage of 40 kV and current of 40 mA, with 2θ ranging from 10° to 90° at a scanning speed 0.02°/1 s. The XRD patterns were collected for the calcined samples. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) was used to evaluate the presence of vacancies in the ceria lattice. The samples were characterized in their reduced states, for which they were firstly dried at 150 °C for 30 min using N2 (40 mL min−1), then reduced with 50% H2/N2 (80 mL min−1) at 170 °C (10 °C min−1) for 1 h and finally purged in a flow of argon during 2 h. The spectra were recorded on a Bruker ESP 300e spectrometer operating in the X-band (9.7 GHz) at room temperature using a microwave power of 20 mW, amplitude modulation of 5 G and frequency modulation of 100 kHz. Signals in the high-field region, with g values corresponding to the free electron (2.0024), were simulated using the easy spin routine from MATLAB software. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were recorded using a Varian Cary 500 spectrophotometer equipped with a Harrick diffuse reflectance accessory with Praying Mantis geometry and range of 200–800 nm. BaSO4 was used as reference and the Kubelka-Munk (F(R)) as function. The samples were not pretreated. The isopropanol dehydration/dehydrogenation was used in order to access the acid-base properties of the catalysts. Formation of acetone is usually associated with basic properties, whereas formation of propene may be related to the acidic properties of the catalyst. The CeO2 materials were initially dried at 130 °C for 30 min under N2 flow (30 mL min−1) and reduced under 50% H2/N2 flow (50 mL min−1) at 500 °C (10 °C min−1) for 1 h. After that, the catalysts were oxidized under synthetic air flow (30 mL min−1) at 500 °C for 30 min. The activity measurements were carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor at 1 atm and 200 °C, using 200 mg of catalyst diluted in 1000 mg of SiC. Reactants and products were analyzed using on-line GC (Agilent 6850) equipped with FID detector. The number of basic sites was determined by temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920. The CO2 adsorption was conducted at room temperature for 1 h (20 mL min−1). The measurements were carried at 20 °C min−1 under He flow (50 mL min−1) from 25 °C to 500 °C. The profiles were decomposed in Gaussian curves in order to quantify the weak, medium and strong basic sites. The weak sites are related to a curve which shows a maximum at a temperature lower than 127 °C, the medium sites between 127 °C and 307 °C, and above 307 °C, strong basic sites. The catalysts were pre-treated with the same conditions of the TPR analysis. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst performance The turnover number (TON), expressed as mmol of DMC formed per mmol of catalyst, methanol conversion and DMC selectivity over the prepared catalysts are depicted in Table 1 . Besides DMC, dimethoxymethane (DMM) and methyl formate (MF) were identified as products in the liquid and gas phases. These by-products are formed from secondary reactions. A proposed mechanistic pathway is shown in Scheme 2 . Lower concentration of Cu (0.02 and 0.04 wt%) on CeO2 increases the TON of DMC by approximately four-fold. However, when employing higher concentrations of this metal the effect is less relevant. At the conditions used, DMM was the main product over CeO2. As indicated in Scheme 2, the formation of these products involves the oxidation or dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, with the subsequent acetalization. On the other hand, for higher loading of Cu, MF selectivity tends to increase. This trend agrees with the results reported by Wada et al. [30]. On the other hand, the catalysts with low and high concentration of Cu (0.02 and 0.5 wt%) showed the best DMC selectivity. To better understand the effect of Cu doping on the catalytic behavior of CeO2, we investigated in more details the catalysts doped with 0.02 wt% and 0.5 wt% of Cu in comparison with the pure CeO2. 3.2 Characterization of the prepared catalysts Catalytic test exhibits good reproducibility indicating that the preparation leads to homogeneous catalysts. The specific areas of the CeO2, 0.02Cu/Ce and 0.5Cu/Ce catalysts are 52, 57 and 56 m2/g, respectively, which indicated similar textural properties. This occurs due to the low Cu concentration used in the preparations. The diffractograms of the CeO2, 0.02Cu/Ce and 0.5Cu/Ce catalysts (Fig. S1 of the Supporting Information) exhibits only peaks associated to the CeO2 cubic structure (fluorite phase) with space group Fm-3m and crystallite size of approximately 11 nm. Moreover, it is not possible to detect changes in the CeO2 crystalline structure when Cu is added to this oxide, within the loadings used in this study. No diffraction peak related to Cu phase (CuO or Cu2O) could be observed, which probably results from the low metal content. The UV–Vis diffuse reflectance spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The 0.02Cu/Ce catalyst and parent CeO2 show similar UV–Vis spectra. Two absorption bands at 241 and 291 nm can be observed and were ascribed to charge transfer transitions: O2− → Ce3+ and O2− → Ce4+, respectively [41–43]. The spectrum of 0.5Cu/Ce exhibits a broad band around 311 nm. Considering the spectra of CuO and CeO2, this broad band can be associated not only with O2− → Cu2+ charge transfer transition of CuO [41,44], but also with the CeO2 absorptions. The spectra of the CeO2 doped with Cu show that, as the concentration of this metal changes from 0.5% to 0.02%, the nature of the Cu species seems to change as well. Fig. 2 displays the H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts. Ceria shows two broad peaks, one at 532 °C and other at 839 °C. The first one is related to the elimination of the surface capping oxygen of this oxide and the second is associated to the reduction of the bulk of the particles [6,7,45]. On 0.02Cu/Ce, both peaks shift to lower temperatures. Moreover, the H2 consumption of the first peak increases around 10% compared with CeO2 (636 µmol g−1). These results show that the Cu species facilitates the reduction of CeO2. When this oxide is doped with a higher amount of Cu (0.5Cu/Ce), there appear a peak around 157 °C and two shoulders at 221 and 469 °C. However, the peak associated with the reduction of the bulk CeO2 does not change much. It can be proposed that CuO is reduced to Cuo during the TPR and after that, this metal behaves as a catalyst in order to promote the reduction of CeO2. This result is in line with the behavior of other metals in the reduction of CeO2 [46]. Despite the reduction at lower temperature, the amount of H2 consumption (641 µmol g−1) of this first peak is similar to the CeO2 catalyst with low concentration of Cu. The UV–Vis and H2-TPR results suggest that at higher Cu concentration, CuO and CeO2 seem to be the most important species. At lower Cu concentration, the TPR profiles suggest an interaction between this metal and the CeO2 lattice. Fig. 3 A and B exhibits the CeO2, 0.02Cu/Ce and 0.5Cu/Ce EPR spectra in their reduced states (reduction was carried out at 170 °C). All three catalysts show two paramagnetic signals related to Ce3+ (g⊥ = 1.97 and gII = 1.94), which can be assigned to Ce3+ species next to unpaired electrons (O−2 and O−) and Ce3+ ions stabilized by some lattice defects, respectively [47]. The EPR spectrum of 0.02Cu/Ce shows a high intensity signal V associated with isolated oxygen vacancies (isolated paramagnetic centers) at g⊥ = 2.04 and gII = 2.02. The spectrum of 0.5Cu/Ce exhibits g⊥ = 2.33 and gII = 2.05 related to the mononuclear component of Cu2+ (hyperfine-split peaks). On the one hand, the spectrum of 0.02Cu/Ce shows the presence of vacancies. It can be suggested that Cu2+ substitutes Ce4+ into the CeO2 lattice generating oxygen vacancies [48]. In contrast, the 0.5Cu/Ce spectrum shows the presence of Cu2+ which is associated with CuO on the surface of CeO2. However, it is not possible to infer the existence of oxygen vacancies on the 0.5Cu/Ce catalyst. These results are consistent with the H2-TPR and UV–Vis data. The CO2-TPD profiles of the catalysts are shown in Table 2 and the deconvoluted CO2-TPD curves in Fig. S2. All catalysts exhibit almost the same numbers of weak + medium basic sites, whereas the number of strong basic sites increases as the Cu concentration increases as well. Table 2 also depicts the rates of formation of propene and acetone upon dehydration and dehydrogenation of isopropanol, respectively. The isopropanol conversion was employed as model reaction to determine the acid and base properties of the catalyst [49,50]. All the materials showed low activity towards isopropanol dehydration (Table 2), consistent with the more basic character of CeO2. However, the addition of Cu to CeO2 (0.02Cu/Ce and 0.5Cu/Ce) favored dehydrogenation, in agreement with the increase in basicity. The higher formation of acetone on 0.5 Cu/Ce may be also attributed to the presence of CuO particles. 3.3 Catalytic evaluation The effect of reaction time and temperature using 0.02Cu/Ce as catalyst is shown in Fig. 4 A. The selectivity to DMC decreases with time, whereas the selectivity to DMM increases for longer periods, suggesting that one product is formed at the expenses of the other. This may be possibly explained by the equilibrium of the two reactions. At the beginning, DMC is formed faster than DMM and its selectivity is high (around 80%). Formation of DMM requires the initial production of formaldehyde, from methanol oxidation or dehydrogenation, which then reacts with methanol. Nevertheless, the increase of the water concentration in the medium upon the production of DMM may shift the equilibrium of the reaction to form DMC, as it is severely limited by thermodynamics, resulting in the decrease of the concentration of this product in the reaction medium and, therefore, its selectivity for longer times. Fig. 4B shows that the selectivity to DMC is higher at lower temperatures, consistent with the exothermicity of the reaction. Therefore, 100% selectivity to DMC was observed at 140 °C. Increasing temperature diminishes the selectivity to DMC, whistle favoring the formation of by-products, especially DMM. The formation of this later product involves the oxidation or dehydrogenation of methanol to formaldehyde, which does not seem to be kinetically favored at lower temperatures. We chose 140 °C and 3 h to compare the catalytic performance, in terms of methanol conversion and selectivity to DMC, DMM and MF, of the three catalysts. The results are shown in Fig. 5 . The CeO2 catalyst exhibits high selectivity to DMC (Fig. 5). This oxide shows strong basic sites (Table 2), which may be associated with the CO2 adsorption, generation of methoxide species and the condensation steps in the synthesis of DMC [26,27]. However, it also generated DMM. This product is explained in terms of oxidation of methanol to formaldehyde and its further reaction with methanol. Formaldehyde can be synthesized by dehydrogenation or oxidative dehydrogenation of methanol. Both show rate limiting steps promoted by strong basic sites [20]. Fig. 5 shows that doping CeO2 with 0.02 wt% of Cu leads to a highly selective catalyst, with 100% selectivity to DMC at 140 °C. This catalyst shows a higher number of strong basic sites than CeO2 (Table 2) and also shows oxygen vacancies, which are believed to be associated with the strong basicity [51]. The higher number of strong basic sites compared with CeO2 seems to favor the CO2 adsorption, inhibiting formaldehyde generation and, consequently, the formation of DMM and MF at lower temperatures (Fig. 4A). Fig. 5 also shows that this catalyst is not only more selective, but also more active than CeO2 and 0.5Cu/Ce. The high selectivity to methyl formate (MF) over 0.5Cu/Ce can be explained by the state of the Cu on this catalyst. UV–Vis and EPR results indicated the formation of CuO on the CeO2 surface at higher copper loading, which may be partially reduced to Cuo at the reaction conditions, thus favoring dehydrogenation steps that are of prime importance in the mechanistic pathway to methyl formate. 3.4 Use of 2-cyanopyridine and methyl trichloroacetate as dehydrating agents The reaction of CO2 with methanol is limited by thermodynamics (Scheme 1). Hence, low methanol conversion is usually obtained if no dehydrating agent is added to the medium to shift equilibrium. We have studied the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol over 0.02Cu/Ce catalyst using 2-cyanopyridine (2-CP) and methyl trichloroacetate (MTCL) as dehydrating agents. The results are presented in Table 3 . The use of MTCL led to the highest TON of DMC formation, more than two-fold higher compared with 2-CP, a traditional and well-studied dehydrating agent for the synthesis of DMC over ceria-based catalysts. Nevertheless, the selectivity to DMC was about 80%, with formation of DMM and minor amounts of MF. The production of both by-products can be explained through the formation of trichloroacetic acid upon the hydrolysis of MTCL. Acetalization is an acid-catalyzed reaction and favored by the presence of a strong acid in the medium [40,52]. The good performance of MTCL as dehydrating agent for the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol may be ascribed to its reactivity toward hydrolysis [37]. In control experiments of the hydrolysis of MTCL and 2-CP at 65 °C and 2 h, using Amberlyst-15 as acid catalyst, 2-CP was not converted, whereas MTCL showed around 82% conversion. The difference in reactivity may explain the better results found with MTCL as dehydrating agent compared with 2-CP. It must be stressed that the molar ratio of methanol to the dehydrating agent was only 10% of the stoichiometric value due to the reduced amount of the reactants. The main intent of the experiments was to compare the two dehydrating agents. Recent studies [33,53–55] have shown that the combined use of CeO2 and 2-cyanopyridine leads to high yields of DMC. However, the hydrolysis of the nitrile generates 2-picolinamide and others by-products, which are somewhat difficult to be reconverted to the original nitrile. The use of trichloroacetic ester, besides giving higher yields of DMC compared with 2-CP, offers the advantage of the potential recovery of the carboxylic acid generated upon hydrolysis (Fig. 6 ) that can be recycled to the ester, making the whole process more sustainable. We have not studied the recovery of the trichloroacetic acid formed, but we were able to detect it, in control experiments, upon the neutralization of the liquid phase at the end of the reaction. It might be also possible that the use of dehydrating agent, such as 2-CP and MTCL might also affect the catalytic properties of the CeO2, because water may interact with the oxygen vacancies. Finally, the method of DMC production using CO2 suffers from low productivity compared to the others methods due to thermodynamic limitations. However, in addition to preventing atmospheric problems, this gas is cheap, non-toxic and abundant, being the preferred feedstock for the synthesis of DMC. The methanol may come from CO2 hydrogenation [56,57] or biomass gasification [58]. 4 Conclusions Loading of small concentrations of Cu on CeO2 increases the formation of oxygen vacancies, associated with strong basicity, as shown by EPR, UV–Vis, CO2-TPD and isopropanol conversion. Higher Cu loading leads to the deposition of CuO phase on the surface of CeO2. The Cu-doped CeO2 catalysts were more active than pure CeO2 in the reaction of methanol with CO2 at 140 °C. Nevertheless, the selectivity varied with the amount of Cu. The material with 0.5 wt% of Cu produced methyl formate as the main product, together with DMC. This is explained by the presence of CuO phase, which favors dehydrogenation steps, present in the mechanistic pathway to methyl formate. On the other hand, 0.02Cu/Ce showed 100% selectivity to DMC, which presents the highest conversion, consistent with the stronger basicity associated with the oxygen vacancies in the lattice. Dimethoxymethane (DMM) was also formed over CeO2, consistent with the lower basicity of this catalyst. The results indicated that at low Cu loading, Cu2+ substitutes Ce4+ species in the CeO2 lattice, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancies, which are associated with basic sites. The use of 0.02Cu/Ce and methyl trichloroacetate (MTCL) seems to be promising in the synthesis of DMC from CO2 and methanol. The use of a dehydrating agent is necessary to shift the equilibrium of the reaction to achieve high conversion. Compared to 2-cyanopyridine, a traditional dehydrating agent used together with ceria-based catalyst, methyl trichloroacetate exhibited more than two-fold higher DMC yield using 0.02Cu/Ce as catalyst. The better result may be associated with the higher reactivity of MTCL toward hydrolysis. Acknowledgments The authors thank the financial support from CAPES, CNPq and FAPERJ. We also thank Centro Brasileiro de Pesquisas Físicas (CBPF) for the EPR measurements. Authors acknowledge the help of Priscila C. Zonetti, Luciano H. Chagas, Sidnei Brum and Isadora P. P da Silva to conduct this work. Appendix A Supplementary material Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcat.2019.01.035. coredata.dc:description: The effect of copper as dopant on ceria (CeO2) was investigated in the direct synthesis of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) from CO2 and methanol. Ceria with different copper loadings (0.02 and 0.5 wt%) was synthesized using the dry impregnation method and characterized by H2-TPR, XRD, EPR, UV–VIS/DRS, acid-base properties and N2 physisorption. CeO2 with 0.02 wt% of Cu showed the highest catalytic activity and selectivity to DMC, mostly due to its basic sites, associated with the presence of oxygen vacancies. Higher Cu concentration (0.5 wt%) promotes dehydrogenation, favoring the formation of methyl formate as the main product. Pure CeO2 also produced dimethoxymethane as by-product. To circumvent the thermodynamic limitations of the reaction, methyl trichloroacetate was tested as dehydrating agent, showing superior performance than 2-cyanopyridine, due to its higher reactivity toward hydrolysis.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of dimethyl carbonate from CO2 and methanol over CeO2: Role of copper as dopant and the use of methyl trichloroacetate as dehydrating agent
